name: Leegin Creative Leather Products, Inc. v. PSKS, Inc.
reasoningForIncluding: The fact that a case involves property rights or contract rights, where reliance interests are involved, argues against overruling.
This case involves contract rights and perhaps property rights.
Congress relied upon the continued vitality of Dr. Miles when it repealed Miller-Tydings and McGuire.
The Executive Branch argued for repeal on the assumption that Dr. Miles stated the law.
Whole sectors of the economy have come to rely upon the per se rule.
The fact that a rule of law has become “embedded” in our “national culture” argues strongly against overruling.

precedent.name: National Soc. of Professional Engineers v. United States
United States v. Arnold, Schwinn & Co.
